Imagine having a chip implanted (after puberty) at the base of your neck which grows molecular tendrils into your brain and stores every sensation and thought that you experience. You become a perfect court witness as you now can recall every event with exact detail. Every day or week, the implanted chip’s data is downloaded to a server farm so that all of your memories are stored outside of your body in case of accidental injury.What’s more, upon reaching your physical prime, your physical body is cloned and embryonic copies are held in suspended animation. That way, if you suffer body death, one of the embryos can be grown under accelerated conditions, a new chip implanted, and your memory restored via an upload from the server farm where all of your memories are stored. Hey presto! You are alive once more.In addition, as your body wears out from old age, a new one can be grown and updated with all of your memories,This is one excellent example of how a physiological merger of the human body and advanced technology will create a “tipping point” in the future. It is equally likely that some segments of the human population will eschew such augmentation and, like the Amish, live without these modern advances.Read Hamilton’s work to see how he explores the physical and moral implications of biotek. It will answer a lot of your questions.
